item.title: Who's Afraid Of Virginia Woolf 9/24/2015 7:30 PM - 10/3/2015 10:30 PM
item.description:
NIU's Procuction of Who's Afraid of Virigina Woolf? Written By Edward Albee
This 1962 dramatic comedy by Edward Albee examines the vitriolic dismemberment of the marriage of middle-aged couple, Martha and George. George is a burned-out associate history professor and Martha is simply an unhappy shrew, and they have grown tired of only pushing each other’s buttons. Late one evening, following a college faculty party where the alcohol has flowed freely, they have invited an unwitting younger couple, Nick and Honey, as guests for a nightcap. Nick is a new assistant professor of biology, and despite the late hour has readily accepted the invitation, because he knows Martha’s father is the university president. As jabs and nasty comments begin to flow as freely as the alcohol, it takes little time for the older couple to draw the younger twosome into their frustrated relationship. As hilarious as it is disturbing, Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf? presents one of theatre’s most infamous dysfunctional couples. The dialogue in the first act of the play has been hailed by some critics as some of the greatest in all of the American theatre. Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf? won both the 1963 Tony Award for Best Play and the 1962–63 New York Drama Critics' Circle Award for Best Play. It is frequently revived on the modern stage. The film adaptation was released in 1966, written by Ernest Lehman, directed by Mike Nichols, and starred Richard Burton, Elizabeth Taylor, George Segal and Sandy Dennis.
Performances Thursday, September 24 7:30pm Friday, September 25 7:30pm Saturday, September 26 7:30pm Sunday, September 27 2:00pm Thursday, October 1 7:30pm Friday, October 2 7:30pm Saturday, October 3 2:00pm & 7:30pm

item.title: Stop Motion Animation 9/26/2015 9:00 AM - 9/26/2015 12:00 PM
item.description: Create your own stop-motion animation video! This class will cover the tools and techniques required to make short animations from real objects. Over two classes, students will conceive and create their own stop-motion animation project, complete with characters, backdrops and effects. Students will gain experience using cameras and digital video production techniques, as well as developing creativity as they design and produce their own story. This course will be held at our Naperville campus and is recommended for ages 10 and up. This is a 2-part class. The second class takes place on September 26th. Morning Session: 9:00am- 12.00pm OR Afternoon session 1.00pm-4.00pm $79 for 2-class session

item.title: STEM Divas Robotics 9/26/2015 9:00 AM - 9/26/2015 1:00 PM
item.description: Join us for a fun LEGO Robotics class exploring the basic programming concepts, and introducing the functions of the LEGO Mindstorms robots. Learn from experienced female engineers how to design your own robot while exploring the role robots play in our life and how they can be used to solve real world problems. No prior experience with programming or robotics is needed. Recommended ages 7 and up. $39 for one class session

item.title: Walk & Roll for Mobility 9/26/2015 8:30 AM - 9/26/2015 11:30 AM
item.description:
Are you ready to "Walk & Roll"?
On Saturday, September 26, two independent, privately-owned physical therapy clinics will host "Walk & Roll For Mobility," a 1.6 one-way walk along the DeKalb Nature Trail from Creative Therapeutics, 400 E. Hillcrest Drive in DeKalb, to Northern Rehab Physical Therapy Specialists 232 W. Lincoln Highway, DeKalb office. The event proceeds will benefit the Voluntary Action Center (VAC). Fun for the whole family – bikes, strollers, walking sticks, and skates welcome!
“Walk & Roll for Mobility” helps kick-off National Physical Therapy Month in October, and allows both independent clinics support a non-profit community organization. On event day, check in begins at 8:30am at Creative Therapeutics; a walking stick demonstration will be at 8:40am; a dynamic warm up is at 8:50am; raffle prize winners are drawn at 8:55am; and the walk kicks off at 9:00 am. Walk, ride, or roll from Creative Therapeutics to Northern Rehab along the DeKalb Nature Trail. Enjoy live music and refreshments upon arrival at Northern Rehab. Walk round-trip or one-way at this fundraising event; a VAC bus will be available for optional return transport back to Creative Therapeutics.
Pre-registration is suggested; those who pre-register by Sept. 23 will be entered into a drawing for various prizes! Call 815.758.5508 to register. A suggested donation of $5.00 per individual or $10 per family will be collected the day of the event upon check-in. All funds will go directly to the Voluntary Action Center (VAC). While Northern Rehab and Creative Therapeutics are friendly competitors in business, as independent small businesses they share many values. As practitioners they connect with their patients and provide personal and individualized care. Both companies encourage the community to understand that they have the right to choose where you receive care. Hosted by Northern Rehab and Creative Therapeutics – your independent choices for physical therapy- we invite all of our past patients, friends and families, and businesses to participate and celebrate your independence and freedom to move at this fun, family event!
For more information about “Walk & Roll For Mobility”, please visit wholept.com or northernrehabpt.com.

item.title: Unity Hospice Veteran's History Project 9/28/2015 8:00 AM - 10/2/2015 9:00 PM
item.description:
Unity Hospice of Western Illinois invites veterans to share their story of wartime to be submitted to the Library of Congress through the Veterans History Project.
Unity Hospice of Western Illinois is inviting veterans in the Western Illinois suburbs to share their stories of wartime to be submitted to the Library of Congress through a nationally-recognized program called the Veterans History Project. One of the world’s most respected research and cultural institutions, the Library of Congress will preserve these stories for future generations so they can better understand American history and the realities of war.
Interested veterans are invited to contact Unity Hospice to schedule an appointment to share their personal stories in the form of unedited video recorded interviews. Interviews will be conducted during the week of September 28 – October 2, 2015. Read more about the Veterans History Project on their website at http://www.loc.gov/vets/.
For more information about the Veterans History Project in your community or to schedule a time to share your story, please contact Unity Hospice Director of Program Development Brenda McGarvey at (618) 954-6114 or volunteers@unityhospice.com.
Unity Hospice of Western Illinois 1201 S. 7th Street, Suite 101 Rochelle, IL 61068

item.title: Pet Blessing 10/4/2015 1:00 PM - 10/4/2015
item.description: St. Paul’s Episcopal Church invites the public to bring their favorite four-legged friends and other creatures to a Pet Blessing Celebration, Sunday, October 4 at 1:00 p.m. at 900 Normal Road in DeKalb. The Pet Blessing is traditionally celebrated the first Sunday in October on the Feast Day of St. Francis of Assisi, who was known for his affection toward animals of all kinds. The public is invited to bring their pets for a celebration of their life, as well as a personal blessing from Rev. Amy Fallon, Director of Grace Place Ministries, NIU Campus. Photographs may also be brought to honor pets that prefer not to travel. The celebration will be held in front of St. Paul’s Episcopal Church, located at 900 Normal Road in DeKalb.

item.title: The Normal Heart 10/8/2015 7:30 PM - 10/11/2015 9:30
item.description:
NIU's Production of The Normal Heart written by Larry Kramer From the Foreword to The Normal Heart: Larry Kramer's The Normal Heart is a play in the great tradition of Western drama. In taking a burning social issue and holding it up to public and private scrutiny so that it reverberates with the social and personal implications of that issue, The Normal Heart reveals its origins in the theater of Sophocles, Euripides, and Shakespeare. In his moralistic fervor, Larry Kramer is a first cousin to nineteenth-century Ibsen and twentieth-century Odets and other radical writers of the 1930s. Yet, at the heart of The Normal Heart, the element that gives this powerful political play its essence, is love—love holding firm under fire, put to the ultimate test, facing and overcoming our greatest fear: death. I love the ardor of this play, its howling, its terror and its kindness. It makes me very proud to be its producer and caretaker. — JOSEPH PAPP
Performances: Thursday, October 8 7:30 pm Friday, October 9 7:30 pm Saturday, October 10 2:00 pm Saturday, October 10 7:30 pm Sunday, October 11 2:00

item.title: Mental Health First Aid Certification 10/9/2015 8:00 AM - 10/9/2015 5: PM
item.description:
You are more likely to encounter a person in an emotional crisis than someone in cardiac arrest. Would you know what to do?
group of students Mental Health First Aid is an evidenced-based public education program that teaches the key skills needed to help someone with a mental health problem or crisis. This nationally-recognized certification focuses on the skills that can be used until professional help is obtained.

item.title: Kishwaukee Symphony Orchestra's Fall Concert: Voilà Viola 10/10/2015 7:30 PM - 10/10/2015 9:00 PM
item.description:
The KSO will perform its Fall Concert: Voilà Viola, on Saturday, Oct. 10, at 7:30 pm, in the Boutell Memorial Concert Hall inside the Music Building, Northern Illinois University, DeKalb. There will be a free pre-concert lecture beginning at 6:30, in the Recital Hall. This concert will feature the Brandenburg Concerto No. 6, by Johann Sebastian Bach; Der Schwanendreher, by Paul Hindemith, with Anthony Devroye, viola; and The Enigma Variations, by Edward Elgar. This concert is supported in part by the Kishwaukee Symphony Associates.
All seats are general admission (no reserved seating). Individual ticket prices are $15 for adults, $10 for seniors 62 and over, $10 for students, and $5 for children under 12. Season tickets may be purchased at special prices for the four regular concerts of the season. Season ticket prices are $50 for adults, $35 for seniors, $35 for students, and $18 for children under 12.

Tickets are AVAILABLE THAT NIGHT AT THE DOOR for $12.00 CASH ONLY. Proceeds benefit the USO. Bottled water will be available for purchase. NO ALCOHOL ALLOWED. Please follow the link below to Facebook for additional information on the dance.

item.title: Breakfast Briefings at Kishwaukee College 10/20/2015 7:45 AM - 10/20/2015 9:30 AM
item.description:
Attract Quality Talent with Creative Marketing with Brian Oster
Your Marketing – website, recruiting brochure, tradeshow booth, etc. – all leave a perception in the eye of the viewer. What does yours say? Are potential top-notch employees being turned off by what they see? This interactive session will help you examine your existing recruiting and marketing efforts, then provide you with immediate tools and short-term creative marketing tactics to begin changing your audience’s perception.
Brian Oster is the Creative Director of OC Imageworks with more than 15 years experience in the advertising industry. After working for a decade as an in-house marketer, he made the transition to agency work, allowing his creative ideas to flourish. A student of his clients – always learning about their industries and their customers – he believes every marketing piece should influence and engage its specified audience. Brian is a graduate of Augustana College with two Bachelor’s Degrees, and recently a graduate of the DeKalb Chamber Leadership Academy. He was quickly accepted into the business community and immediately began demonstrating his servant leadership. Brian is the committee chair for the Leadership Academy Advisory Committee, board member of Family Service Agency, and involved in several other area organizations.

item.title: Three Sisters 10/22/2015 7:30 PM - 10/31/2015 10:30 PM
item.description: Three Sisters Written by Anton Chekhov In a provincial town somewhere in Russia, the three Prozorov sisters—Olga, Masha and Irina— and their brother Andrei, live in the large, beautiful house they inherited from their father. Transplanted from Moscow eleven years earlier when the father, a brigadier general, took command of an artillery unit in the garrison town, they are very conscious of their superior status, education, refinement and taste. On the one year anniversary of their father's death, they now long to escape. They have become acutely aware of their dreary backwoods existence, stranded amongst small town folk with no ambition or appreciation of the finer things they have deluded themselves into remembering of the bright, thriving city they left as children. Although they can pack up their worldly possessions and leave at any time, they will not and perhaps simply cannot. They instead wallow in lethargy, made bearable only by the visits of officers from the nearby artillery post, the only locals who are of their class. However, the visitations soon fuel love affairs, flared tempers and deadly duels and turn the proper Prozorov home into a place where anything can happen. In Three Sisters, Russian playwright, Anton Chekhov conveys the wasting away of the upper class in a coarse environment, but with an incomparable ability to subtly demonstrate the psychic and spiritual costs of inaction. Three Sisters is considered a masterpiece of world literature and is presented in repertoire by theatre companies across the globe. Performances Thursday, October 22 7:30pm Friday, October 23 7:30pm Saturday, October 24 7:30pm Sunday, October 25 2:00pm Thursday, October 29 7:30pm Friday, October 30 7:30pm Saturday, October 31 2:00pm & 7:30pm

item.title: Measure for Measure 11/5/2015 7:30 PM - 11/8/2015 9:30 PM
item.description:
NIU's Production of Measure for Measure written by William Shakespeare Unexpectedly, the Duke of Vienna leaves his throne and appoints young Angelo to govern in his absence. In response to seeing the moral decay around him, the newly appointed ruler resurrects an old law that treats adultery as a capital crime. In principle, he is committed to the ideals behind this law. In practice, real life and its complications interfere with the purity of his vision. Innocent victims and collateral damage appear at his doorstep and in his heart. Measure for Measure has been classified by scholars as a problem play “characterized by its complex and ambiguous tone, which shifts violently between dark, psychological drama and more straightforward comic material.” Perhaps it is the absence of easy answers that attracts us to this Shakespeare story.
Performances: Thursday, November 5 @ 7:30 pm Friday, November 6 @ 7:30 pm Saturday, November 7 @ 2:00 pm Saturday, November 7 @ 7:30 pm Sunday, November 8 @ 2:00

item.title: The Dean Martin & Jerry Lewis Tribute Show 11/7/2015 7:30 PM - 11/7/2015 10:30 PM
item.description: Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis were the hottest act in America during the early 50’s. Dean of course, the straight man, with a charming voice and Jerry the lovable goof ball added the comedy. Never have two artists captured the look, the sound, the very essence and chemistry of these two “Icons” more than Tome Stevens and Tony Lewis. You don’t want to miss this evening of unpredictable hysterical music and laughter! Both of these incredible performers have each had amazing success on their own. Tony spent the last 27 years performing in Australia and created a name for himself as the quintessential “Jerry Lewis Tribute Artist” selling out countless venues and earned respect as one of Australia’s best entertainers. Since his 1st appearance at the annual Dean Martin Festival in 1998, Tom Stevens has earned his title as “Best Dean Martin Tribute Artist.” Even Dean’s daughter, Deana said, “I’ve never seen anyone look and sound more like my Daddy!”

In these classes students will make their own basic circuits and program the Arduinos to look for and respond to input from sensors and controls. Some previous experience with electronics and programming is recommended for this course, but not required. This course will be held at our Naperville campus, and is recommended for ages 12 and up. This is a 2-part class. The second class takes place on November 14th. $79 for 2-class session

item.title: Quarantine: The Field Trip Presented by STEM Read 11/19/2015 9:00 AM - 11/19/2015 2:00 PM
item.description:
Join NIU STEM Read for our most terrifyingly educational field trip yet! Students and school groups in grade 8 and up can--
-Experience a day-long, live-action game based on "Quarantine: The Loners" by Lex Thomas -Work in groups to solve hands-on challenges related to microbiology, human health, disaster management, costume design, engineering, and economics -Meet authors Lex Hrabe and Tom Voorhies -Learn from experts from NIU and Argonne National Lab
Note that this field trip will contain loud noises, flashing lights, disaster simulations, and colored hair spray. Students should wear sneakers and clothes they don't mind getting dirty.
$10 per student includes registration and pizza party lunch.
Check in begins at 8:30AM
Learn more and register at stemread.com/fieldtrips

item.title: NIU SOTD Fall 2015 Dance Concert 11/19/2015 7:30 PM - 11/22/2015 10:30 PM
item.description: Fall 2015 Dance Concert The fall dance production features a cornucopia of performance styles from classic to modern ballet and everything in between, all choreographed by faculty of the School of Theatre and Dance. The Esmeralda Ballet will be restaged by Judith Chitwood, a contemporary ballet restaged by Rich Grund, with additional modern works mounted by Paula Frasz and Autumn Eckman. The production will also feature a remount of the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zale Dance Company choreographed modern work, Days Spent Out Yonder, which was performed by SoTD this past spring at the Ruth Page Center for the Arts in Chicago. The production features a new work choreographed to the music of Handel, called “Drama Queens.” Performances Thursday, November 19 7:30pm Friday, November 20 7:30pm Saturday, November 21 7:30pm Sunday, November 22 2:00pm

item.title: STEM Divas Virtual Reality 11/21/2015 9:00 AM - 11/21/2015 1:00 PM
item.description: This class is for our STEM Divas that are curious about animation, computers, video games and how they all work together. They will learn the essentials of video game design while developing a story to design their own game. STEMDivas will be able to develop basic virtual space and create sound effects while having fun at our own NIU Digital Convergence Lab. Recommended ages 7 and up. $39 for one class session

item.title: STEM Divas Virtual Reality 11/21/2015 9:00 AM - 11/21/2015 1:00 PM
item.description: This class is for our STEM Divas that are curious about animation, computers, video games and how they all work together. They will learn the essentials of video game design while developing a story to design their own game. STEMDivas will be able to develop basic virtual space and create sound effects while having fun at our own NIU Digital Convergence Lab. Recommended ages 7 and up. $39 for one class session

item.title: Chemistry Investigations 11/21/2015 9:00 AM - 11/21/2015 12:00 PM
item.description: This is one class that’s sure to get a reaction! Come get a hands-on look at some basic chemistry as students perform fun and easy experiments that will teach them about chemical reactions. We’ll be doing experiments with acids & bases, liquid nitrogen, tie dye, and even making our own glow in the dark slime! Students should also bring an item from home to tie dye. Items should be 100% cotton for best results. Recommend for ages 10 and up. This is a 2-part class. The second class takes place on December 5th. $59 for 2-class session

item.title: 3D Printing Mania 11/21/2015 9:00 AM - 11/21/2015 12:00 PM
item.description: What is 3D printing? Where is 3D printing used? How do you 3D print? Get an answer to all of these questions in our new 3D printing class led by experienced engineers. Learn how to use CAD software to create your own personal figurine to take home, anything from action figures and toy cars to bracelets and toy pets. This is a 2-part class. The second class takes place on December 5th. Morning Session: 9:00am- 12.00pm OR Afternoon session 1.00pm-4.00pm. $79 for 2-class session.

item.title: Women In To Light 12/2/2015 7:30 PM - 12/6/2015 9:30 PM
item.description:
NIU's Production of Women In To Light- Freshman BFA Showcase Women Into Light is a “derived piece,” developed as a cooperative work between actors and directorial staff expressly for the purpose of creating deeper characterizations, through physicality and acting, and a deeper understanding of the real lives of women who have never been portrayed on the stage. Based on research of journals, autobiographies and diaries, the stories will highlight the life histories of forgotten women who have been either overlooked or covered up by history.
Performances: Wednesday, December 2 @ 7:30 pm Thursday, December 3 @ 7:30 pm Saturday, December 5 @ 2:00 pm Saturday, December 5 @ 7:30 pm Sunday, December 6 @ 2:00

item.title: CSA Showcase Recital 12/5/2015 9:00 AM - 12/5/2015
item.description:

This event is free and open to the public.

This concert is free and open to the public.
